data.question: What are the two novel polymetallic ligand-bridged copper redox shuttles introduced in this study?
data.answer: The two novel polymetallic ligand-bridged copper redox shuttles introduced are based on tetradentate ligands 6,6鈥?bis(2,3,4-trihydropyrrol-5-yl)-2,2鈥?bipyridine (Ctetra) and 6,6鈥?bis(4,5-dihydrothiazol-2-yl)-2,2鈥?bipyridine (Stetra).

data.question: How do the structures of the tetradentate redox mediators change depending on the oxidation state of the metal centers?
data.answer: The structures of the tetradentate redox mediators were revealed by XRD as (Cu(I))2 dimers and Cu(II) monomers. The Cu(I) species assemble ligand-bridged dimers, and transition to a monomeric square-planar geometry in the Cu(II) oxidation state.

data.question: What is the proposed mechanism for the dynamic dimer redox mediators in dye-sensitized solar cells?
data.answer: Following electron transfer and single oxidation of the dimers, the calculations suggest a dynamic transition to Cu(II) monomers via a disproportionation mechanism. The tetradentate ligands then stabilize the square-planar Cu(II) monomers and inhibit charge recombination.

data.question: What are the inner reorganization energies for single-electron transfer in the dimeric copper complexes compared to single complexes?
data.answer: Density functional theory calculations reveal inner reorganization energies for single-electron transfer as low as 0.27 eV for the dimeric complexes, marking them as superior redox systems over single complexes as liquid and potentially solid-state electrolytes.

data.question: What is the proposed reason for the reduced voltage losses observed in dye-sensitized solar cells using the dimer redox mediators compared to Cu(tmby)2?
data.answer: The reduced voltage losses were a result of slower recombination rates, as predicted from the either thermodynamically or kinetically unfavored pathways for charge recombination in the dimer redox mediator systems. This is supported by transient photovoltage measurements which showed much longer electron lifetimes at all light intensities for either dimer redox system compared with Cu(tmby)2.

data.question: What techniques were used to characterize the structures of the Cu(I) and Cu(II) complexes of Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra)?
data.answer: The geometries of the dimer and monomer structures were elucidated via single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). DFT was also used to compute the minimum energy structures and electronic features of Cu(II/I) complex monomers and dimers.

data.question: True or False: The Cu(I) monomers are energetically favored over Cu(I) dimers for both Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra).
data.answer: False. The calculations found that Cu(I) dimers are energetically favored over two Cu(I) monomers by 1.16 and 1.36 eV for Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra), respectively, when calculated in a solvent-continuum model.

data.question: What is the proposed reason for the large current densities recorded with the tetradentate redox shuttles in the limiting current measurements?
data.answer: The large current densities reinforce the case of disproportionation of mixed-state dimers and diffusion by individual Cu(II) monomers, rather than diffusion of bulky mixed valence dimers carrying only a single net charge.

data.question: True or False: The impedance response of the symmetric PEDOT || PEDOT cells followed a finite-length Warburg model in the low-frequency regime for both Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra).
data.answer: True. The impedance response followed a finite-length Warburg model in the low-frequency regime for both complexes, indicating that despite potential contributions from electronic self-exchange, ion diffusion is ultimately the limiting transport mechanism.

data.question: What techniques were used to probe the ability of Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra) to regenerate the Y123 dye?
data.answer: The ability of Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra) to regenerate the Y123 dye was probed with photoinduced absorption spectroscopy and transient absorption spectroscopy.

data.question: What were the regeneration efficiencies of Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra) for the Y123 dye compared to Cu(tmby)2?
data.answer: Both redox couples regenerated Y123+ as efficiently as Cu(tmby)2, with regeneration efficiencies of 99.6% and 99.0% for Cu(Ctetra) and Cu(Stetra), respectively.

data.question: True or False: The open circuit voltage of the solar cells with Cu(Stetra) was higher than with Cu(Ctetra).
data.answer: True. The open circuit voltage (VOC) of the solar cells followed the trend of redox potentials as expected, with Cu(Stetra) giving a higher value than Cu(Ctetra) (911 and 881 mV, respectively).

data.question: What is the proposed reason for the fill factor drop observed in Cu(Ctetra)-based devices compared to Cu(Stetra)-based devices?
data.answer: The fill factor drop in Cu(Ctetra)-based devices can be readily attributed to slow kinetics at the electrolyte/PEDOT interface, as discussed in the analysis of electrode kinetics with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy.

data.question: What are the two main conclusions drawn about the dynamic dimer copper redox systems presented in this study?
data.answer: The two main conclusions are: 1) These redox couples offer a novel combination of fast charge transport in a two-electron redox mechanism while inhibiting carrier recombination after disproportionation. 2) The presented dynamic dimer copper complexes open a new design scheme for redox mediators, combining comprehensive control of recombination and rapid charge transport in hybrid solar cells and potentially in batteries and other emerging technologies.

data.question: What future targets of study are suggested for the dynamic dimer redox systems?
data.answer: Future targets of study should include the degree of disproportionation versus diffusion of single-oxidized dimers of these complexes, as well as the contribution of electronic self-exchange to ionic charge transport in the dynamic dimer redox systems.

data.question: True or False: The syntheses of the Ctetra and Stetra ligands and their associated complexes have been previously reported in the literature.
data.answer: False. The syntheses of the Ctetra and Stetra ligands, and of their associated complexes, are reported here for the first time.

data.question: What level of theory was used for the density functional theory calculations in this study?
data.answer: DFT calculations were performed at the B3LYP level of theory, including Grimmes dispersion correction D3 with the Becke-Johnson damping function. The SDD effective core potential and basis set was used for Cu and a 6-31++G(d,p) basis set for all other atoms.

data.question: What is the proposed reason for the better performance of Cu(Stetra)-based devices compared to Cu(Ctetra)-based devices?
data.answer: The better performance of Cu(Stetra)-based devices can be attributed to the less negative Gibbs free energy for dimer disproportionation for Cu(Stetra) (-0.19 eV) compared to Cu(Ctetra) (-0.60 eV). This suggests that the mechanism of disproportionation and monomer diffusion dominates more for Cu(Ctetra), whereas mixed valence dimer diffusion likely contributes more to the charge transport for Cu(Stetra).

data.question: True or False: The photocurrent densities collected by the tetradentate redox couples from the Y123 dye were significantly higher than those obtained with Cu(tmby)2.
data.answer: False. Despite the much higher diffusion limit and larger driving force, the photocurrent densities collected by the tetradentate redox couples from the Y123 dye did not improve greatly over Cu(tmby)2. The exact mechanism and kinetics of charge transport in copper redox dimer electrolytes, especially through a dye-sensitized mesoporous scaffold, remains to be further investigated.

data.question: What techniques were used to characterize the Cu(I/II) complexes in this study?
data.answer: The Cu(I/II) complexes were characterized using various techniques including single-crystal X-ray diffraction, density functional theory calculations, UV-Vis spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, Raman spectroscopy, NMR spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, and scanning electron microscopy.
